awd_titl_txt: Building Capacity by Strengthening Pathways and Recruitment Strategies for Future STEM Teachers through a Community College and University Partnership
awd_abstract_narration:
The project aims to serve the national need of building capacity to address the challenge of teacher shortages in high-need school districts particularly in STEM areas. The intention of this proposal is to develop clear pathways from the community college into the main university campus, and to develop an understanding of student perceptions about STEM and the teaching profession to better recruit and prepare STEM teachers. The intended collaboration between Dona Ana Community College (DACC) and New Mexico State University (NMSU) will be essential for building sustainable STEM educator pathways. These partners will work together to create practices that address what STEM undergraduates need to become effective STEM teachers. To accomplish these aims, both institutions will develop STEM degree concentrations to support a future Noyce Track 1 proposal.  Additionally, data analysis aimed at understanding STEM student interest in simultaneously pursuing a major in a STEM discipline and a minor in Secondary Education at both institutions will be used to develop a recruitment plan for Noyce Scholars. As one of six minority-as-majority states, New Mexico’s schooling environment exhibits the complex educational, cultural, and economic challenges occurring throughout the United States. With NMSU located within three school districts along the US-Mexico border and producing only a small number of mathematics or science pre-service teachers, this region echos the national declining trend in teacher production. At the same time, there is a state-wide need for STEM prepared employees in military, space, and agriculturally based industries.  

This project at Dona Ana Community College includes a partnership with New Mexico State University. Project goals include the development of teacher education pathways that allow STEM majors to minor in Education, and the development of a recruitment plan. We will draw on research about the importance of teachers having high levels of content and pedagogical knowledge and intend on centering our recruitment plans on the needs of students from underrepresented minority groups given the demographics of the students at both institutions. Additionally, we will draw on approaches to collaboration that foster organizational boundary-spanning activities that lead to new inter-institutional norms. We will collect data from students through survey research about levels of interest in STEM teaching to design a recruitment plan. This project will allow both institutions to prepare teachers so they can successfully prepare their students for STEM learning despite strained socio-economic supports. Successful strategies implemented and documented from this project can be a model for replication at similar institutions. The independent evaluation approach for this capacity-building project, conducted by the Southwest Outreach Academic Research Evaluation and Policy Center, will be both formative and summative. Project outcomes will be disseminated through local, state, and national conferences.  This Capacity Building project is supported through the Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program (Noyce). The Noyce program supports talented STEM undergraduate majors and professionals to become effective K-12 STEM teachers and experienced, exemplary K-12 teachers to become STEM master teachers in high-need school districts. It also supports research on the effectiveness and retention of K-12 STEM teachers in high-need school districts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
NMSU-Doña Ana Community College (DACC) and New Mexico State University (NMSU), both HSIs, participated in a Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program grant titled Building Capacity by Strengthening Pathways and Recruitment Strategies for Future STEM Teachers through a Community College and University Partnership. DACC is a part of the NMSU system, and NMSU is the primary transfer destination for DACC students. Located within three school districts along the US-Mexico border, these institutions aimed to: 

  1. Formalize STEM degree concentrations (A.S., B.S., and B.A.) that incorporate STEM major requirements and a Minor in Secondary Education leading to teacher licensure. 
  2. Gather data on distinct student populations to more effectively recruit students for these concentrations. 

To achieve these goals, the project brought together academic faculty, university administrators, and external educational advisors. 

Outcomes for Goal 1: 

  • Developed AS and teacher education pathways within STEM programs at the Community College, creating concentrations in four STEM disciplines leading to 4-year degrees at NMSU. 
  • Approved programs in Biology (Secondary Education-BS), Chemistry (Secondary Education-BA and Secondary of Science), and Computer Science (Secondary Education-BA), now included in the NMSU catalog. 
  • Revised the foundational Introduction to Secondary Education and Youth practicum course to focus on educational challenges specific to high-needs school environments. 

Outcomes for Goal 2: 

  • Developed a recruitment plan to attract STEM students to a teacher-preparation pathway. 
  • Collected data on current STEM students through the STEM Education and Workforce Survey. We initially surveyed 101 students and subsequently narrowed this sample down to 1st- and 2nd- year students in Calculus I because these students represent science majors from a broad range of majors, and would be the target for recruitment population for a future Noyce Scholarship
  • Found that the community college, in comparison to the university, had a higher percentage of first-generation students (60% vs 50%), more female students (27% vs 13%), and 9.1% more students choosing Education/Teaching as their first choice. 
  • Identified a strong preference for scholarships, academic, and financial support among students considering teaching, with 94% valuing the chance to change people's lives as a career motivator. 

These results highlight the need to approach STEM teacher recruitment by considering the differences between institutions (student populations, environment, resources), and with an intersectional lens that attends to ethnicity, gender, and first-generation status. These findings informed a recruitment plan with detailed activities, marketing strategies, and selection criteria for potential scholars, targeting partnerships with STEM departments and organizations. Emphasis was placed on financial incentives, academic support, inclusive branding, and storytelling to engage potential applicants, prioritizing diversity and commitment to professional development. 

Advisory Board and Faculty Forum: 

An advisory board provided feedback on curriculum competencies and recruitment strategies, highlighting the need to address the STEM teacher shortage, make teaching attractive to STEM students, and emphasized diversity. An extension of these meetings, a STEM Education Faculty forum, gathered feedback on new concentrations and classroom activities useful for STEM majors. Several strategies were suggested including a focus on analyzing student reasoning, revisiting content knowledge, and modeling teaching methods. 

Conclusion: 

New Mexico's schooling environment faces complex socio-economic challenges, with a need for STEM-prepared professionals. Collaboration between NMSU’s College of A&S, College of HEST, and DACC built a STEM educator pathway to produce future teachers and enhance the regional workforce. Data highlighted differences and commonalities between community colleges and universities, aiding in the development of initiatives to recruit and retain exemplary STEM teachers. As a minority-majority state, New Mexico aims to educate traditionally underserved students and prepare the next generation of scientists, mathematicians, and engineers through clear pathways from community colleges to 4-year degrees. The Noyce grant has united individuals to prioritize improving the quality of STEM teacher education. 

 


Last Modified: 06/18/2024
Modified by: German A Moreno

Gather data on distinct student populations to more effectively recruit students for these concentrations.
